lesson.title: Course Update Available
lesson.summary: Learn about the updated Monolith to Microservices course and how you can access the new content

atoms.text:
## Updated Content!   

In response to student feedback we are launching an updated version of the Monolith to Microservices course to new students. We also want to give you the opportunity to view the updated content if you choose to do so.  


## Where Can I Find the Updated Content?

You can find the updated content in the Extracurriculars section of your classroom.

atoms.caption:
To find the new content, first click on the triangle next to **EXTRACURRICULAR**
and then click on **Monolith to Microservices Update**

atoms.text:
## What Has Been Updated?

### New Instructor

Justin is an engineer specializing in designing modern data platforms and scalable systems. He has been a consultant for Fortune 500 companies and has traveled the world to work with his clients.

atoms.caption: Meet Justin, Our Instructor for the Updated Course
atoms.alt: Meet Justin, Our Instructor for the Updated Course

atoms.text:
### New Lessons We added new lessons at the start and end the of the course: - **Introduction to Microservices**
Introduces the course and provides technical, business, and historical context on why we have microservices.

- **Getting Ready for the Refactor Udagram Project**
Helps you set up the AWS services you will need for the **Refactor Udagram app to Microservices Project** and shares some tips for a successful project.

### Updates to Existing Lessons We kept the same basic structure for the rest of the lessons, but we updated the content based on feedback from students: - **Best Practices for Micro-Services Development** and **Independent Development** have been combined into **Microservices Design Principles and Best Practices**.
The updated lesson includes more context comparing monoliths with microservices and how to choose one over the other. It takes a strategic approach for refactoring a monolith to microservice.

- **Container** is now **Containers Using Docker**.
The updates provide more context on why we use containers and includes a hands-on demonstration on how we can run the same application locally vs. in a container. Strategies to improve Docker performance are also discussed.

- **Independent releases and deployments** now appears earlier in the course in the **Automating the Application Development Lifecycle** lesson.
The updated lesson includes a new focus on hands-on for building out Continuous Integration (CI) and context on how, what, and why continuous integration is used. It also ties in Docker as a building block for continuous integration.

- **Kubernetes** is now **Orchestration with Kubernetes**.
The lesson now includes context on why we use Kubernetes and how it fits in the big picture with Docker and CI. It also discusses how you can streamline the setup of Kubernetes natively on AWS with EKS.

- **Service Registration, Discoveryâ€Š & Scaling** is now **Best Practices/Design Patterns for Kubernetes in Production**.
The updated lesson introduces best practices for scaling and durability using Kubernetes in production as well as best practices for security and forensics for microservices in production. ## Which Course Should I Use? It's up to you. Either course will prepare you for the **Refactor Udagram app to Microservices Project**.
